newsitem.title: FRANCE: Jospin wants French defence firms to consolidate.
newsitem.headline: Jospin wants French defence firms to consolidate.

text.p: Prime Minister Lionel Jospin said on Thursday that France's defence firms must consolidate to boost competitiveness but confirmed that the former centre-right government's plans for an all-volunteer army would go ahead.

"Our (defence) enterprises must consolidate, to restore and increase their competitiveness so they can fully participate in future cooperatiion projects in Europe," Jospin said in a keynote policy address to the National Assembly.

"Europe is important for our defence. The government hopes to instill a new dynamism in the cooperation that will develop in this area. It is thus urgent to adopt a new and more coherent policy for the defence industries," he said.
Conservative President Jacques Chirac decided last year to phase out compulsory military service for men, and Jospin said the timetable for the switch "will be maintained".

But he said he wanted to take a new look at a controversial plan to summon young people to army recruitment centres for five-day "citizens' meetings" including medical tests and lessons on civic values in the event that conscription were to be needed in an emergency.
"The link uniting each citizen to the defence of his country must be better defined," he said.
